chapter.title: Installation of &ganesha;
chapter.para: &ganesha; provides an NFS access to either the &rgw; or the &cephfs;. It supports NFS versions 3, 4, 4.1 and 4.2. &ganesha; runs in the user instead of the kernel space and directly interacts with the &rgw; or &cephfs;.

sect2.title: General Information
sect2.para: To successfully deploy &ganesha;, you need to add a role-ganesha to your /srv/pillar/ceph/proposals/policy.cfg. For details, see . &ganesha; also needs either a role-rgw or a role-mds present in the policy.cfg.

Although it is possible to install and run the &ganesha; server on an already existing &ceph; node, we recommend running it on a dedicated host with an access to the &ceph; cluster. The client hosts are typically not part of the cluster, but they need to have network access to the &ganesha; server.

To enable the &ganesha; server after the initial installation, add the role-ganesha to the /srv/pillar/ceph/proposals/policy.cfg on the &smaster; and re-run at least stages 2 and 4. For details, see .

&ganesha; is configured via the file /etc/ganesha/ganesha.conf that exists on the &ganesha; node. However, this file is overwritten each time &deepsea; stage 4 is executed. Therefore we recommend to edit the template used by &salt; which is the file /srv/salt/ceph/ganesha/files/ganesha.conf.j2 on the &smaster;. For details about the configuration file, see .

sect2.title: Summary of Requirements
sect2.para: The following requirements have to be met, before &deepsea; stages 2 and 4 can be executed to install &ganesha;:

listitem.para: At least one node needs to be assigned the role-ganesha.
You can define only one role-ganesha per minion.
&ganesha; needs either a &rgw; or a &cephfs; to work.
